Since Emma the perfect is flown</br>To the regions of permanent rest,</br>Perversely will Colinet moan,</br>And wish the dear Seraph unblest?
What tho' she were pride of the plain,</br>What tho' she were queen of the dance;</br>What tho' she gave joy to the swain,</br>And rivalled the flowers of romance?
The fair one forsook with a smile</br>The pleasures that once she held dear:</br>For Colinet these are but vile,</br>Compar'd with a bliss more sincere.
What tho' she were joy to your heart,</br>What tho' she were light to your eye;</br>What tho' the kind Fair would impart</br>Each rapture, each tear, and each sigh?
The end of her pilgrimage here,</br>Was to fit her for mansions of bliss;</br>Then indulge not the murmuring tear,</br>Nor lament such an exit as this.
Since Emma the peerless is flown</br>To the regions of permanent rest,</br>Perversely should Colinet moan—</br>He has not a wish to be blest.</br>
